sections.text:
We are entering an age of data explosion. The volume of digital information generated from the internet and from portable and high-definition video devices has doubled every two years since 2000 and will reach 44 zetta bytes (or 44 billion terabytes (TB)) by 2020 according to estimates by the International Data Corporation. In addition, research in fields such as astrophysics, biology, geography, social science and business requires a large amount of data that has to be available over long periods of time1. For example, the Square Kilometre Array (SKA) radio telescope will produce 160 TB of raw data per second, and the recent discovery of gravitational waves2 has stimulated the beginning of century-long astronomic observations. Furthermore, it is reported that the new brain-mapping programme, the Brain Research through Advancing Innovative Neurotechnologies (BRAIN), may eventually handle one yottabyte (1012 TB) of data3. Hence, information will need to be continuously stored and readily accessed over long-term periods. These stringent requirements constitute an insuperable challenge for existing data centres that are based on magnetic hard-disk drives, which have a lifetime of only two years and will utilize 10% of the total commercial electricity in the United States of America in 2020 (REF. 4). Scientists and engineers are now facing the arduous task of further developing data storage devices to obtain higher capacity, longer lifetime and lower energy consumption. In this context, nanomaterials offer solutions with enormous potential. The rise of nanophotonics has brought about various new pathways for light–matter interaction, allowing nanoscale manipulation of materials through the use of laser light. Optical devices implemented using nanomaterials with tailorable properties will lead to extended improvements in information storage for sustainable growth. Optical data storage — which is enabled by the use of microscopy technologies — is a highly promising alternative to contemporary approaches because it has proven to be superior in terms of performance and durability. However, it will be necessary to increase the capacity of currently available devices. Conventional optical systems are ultimately limited by the diffractive nature of light. Consequently, it is necessary to overcome the diffraction limit to realize nano-optical data storage. The invention of far-field super-resolution optical micro scopy, which breaks the diffraction-limit barrier by controlling the on/off switching of the samples under study, has brought about the renaissance of high-capacity optical data storage5. Innovations in the field of nanotechnology have led to the development of many new nanomaterials that are excellent candidates for application in data storage devices (FIG. 1). Nanoscale fabrication enables the use of single or few nanoparticles as information writing units. This emerging class of materials shows unique mechanical, electronic and optical properties compared with their bulk counterparts, owing to the strong confinement of electrons, photons and phonons at the nanoscale. Inorganic nanomaterials are especially suitable for far-field super-resolution techniques, owing to their high one- and two-photon absorption crosssection, wide absorption bandwidth, high quantum yield, long fluorescence lifetime, high photostability and non-photobleaching properties. Moreover, the solubility of inorganic nanomaterials in water or organic solvents allows their incorporation into a convenient host matrix for the large-scale production of cost-effective optical discs. sections.heading: Recent advancements
sections.text:
The optical disc industry evolved from CDs to DVDs and blu-ray discs6 — which have reached a maximum recording capacity of 200 GB and a lifetime of about 30 years — always allowing for backward compatibility. Despite great commercial success in the past, these three generations of formats are now becoming obsolete. They are frequently replaced by other storage media, owing to recent transformations in the storage market. As reported in the roadmap by the International Electronics Manufacturing Initiative, with the increasing volume of data and the advent of cloud computing, users who typically managed all their data locally are switching to cloud storage, relying on data centres and accessing their information through the internet. Accordingly, the storage market is progressively changing its target from consumer to professional-level user. Big data centres, such as those used by global shopping websites and social networks, retain massive quantities of information for prolonged periods of time and with relatively
few deletions. Rarely accessed data, also known as cold data, requires long-term reliability at relatively low cost and with a low environmental impact.
The benchmark parameters for next-generation data storage technologies are as follows. First, storage devices should have a high capacity and a fast time response to allow quick data access. Power consumption has become an important issue and many facilities are eliminating air conditioning to serve as ‘green data centres’ with a minimal impact on the environment. Therefore, storage devices should have low energy consumption. Another requisite is long lifetime to guarantee long-term data preservation and to reduce the cost of frequent migration of data. Finally, the format of the devices should be maintained to enable backward compatibility with existing technology.
For applications in the archival market, the performance targets for optical data storage devices are quantitatively estimated to be petabytes (PB) of storage capacity per disc, a writing/reading speed of gigabits per second and a century-long lifetime. The foreseen energy consumption is of the order of femtojoules per bit of storage, owing to the highly efficient recording and retrieval of information obtained using a laser. These characteristics are highly desirable in a single device and would ultimately reduce the overall costs to only US$0.01 per gigabyte of storage. For applications in the consumer market, a shorter lifetime (for example, 50 years) may be sufficient if the other benchmark parameters can meet the same targets as for the archival market.
Great industrial efforts have been undertaken to fulfil these requirements, and recently the fourth generation of the optical disc has been released (FIG. 2). In 2015, Panasonic and Sony launched archival discs onto the market. Using a double-sided, triple-layer, landand-groove format, the archival disc has a capacity of 300 GB and offers reliable long-term digital storage. According to their industrial development strategies, the two companies are currently working to expand the capacity of the archival disc to 500 GB and 1 TB per disc. Furthermore, there is a plan to use archival disc technology in a new optical library system with archiving capabilities of 181 PB for over 100 years in a data centre environment (temperature, 5 °C; humidity, 20–90%) and with low power consumption (9 kW under typical operating conditions and less than 2 kW in the idle state). Along with conventional methods, many attempts have been made in the past 50 years to commercialize holographic data storage. Between 2001 and 2009, InPhase Technology has announced several prototype devices with a capacity of 300 GB per disc and a lifetime of 50 years7. However, holographic data storage technology has not yet become commercially available.
Intense research efforts have been devoted to breaking through the diffraction limit and achieving superresolution optical data storage to increase the capacity of a single device. Near-field techniques, such as the use of near-field scanning optical micro scopy probes8, solid immersion lenses9 and plasmonic lenses10, represent one of the earliest approaches that have been considered. However, the major drawback of this method is that near-field optical microscopy can operate only in close proximity to the surface of the sample, which restricts its practical use to 2D applications. By contrast, far-field super-resolution techniques have the potential to achieve nano scale 3D optical data storage. In one of the available methods — stimulated emission depletion (STED)11–15 microscopy — two laser beams are used, one for the selective activation and the other for the deactivation of fluorophores, so that only molecules located at the centre of the beam can fluoresce. Similarly, a two-beam optical lithography technique — super-resolution photo-induction-inhibited nanolithography (SPIN)16 — has been developed to write features smaller than the diffraction limit. The mechanisms of photo-inhibition can be photodeactivation17, photochromism18 or photoradical generation16,19. In particular, SPIN has been used to write features with a size of 9 nm in a two-photon absorption polymer16,20, paving the way for an estimated storage capacity of 1 PB per disc5. The combination of nanolithography and superresolution optical microscopy enabled by the use of nanomaterials lays the foundation for 3D bit-by-bit writing and reading of information at the nanoscale. Hence, we can expect that a boost in the capacity of a single optical data storage device will be achieved, while maintaining the format compatibility with currently available systems.
As we mentioned, the lifetime of optical data storage devices is a pivotal issue. Owing to their high thermal and chemical stability, inorganic crystals and glass have been utilized to demonstrate optical data storage with a lifetime of over 1,000 years21,22. Furthermore, the recording and retrieval of digital information have been achieved by using femtosecond laser nanostructuring of fused quartz22. The orientation and the correlated phase retardation of the birefringence of these nanostructures served as additional dimensions for data multiplexing,
a method that is used to combine multiple signals to store them using a shared medium. Fluorescence lifetime has been used as an additional dimension in optical multiplexing by controlling the doping of rare-earth ions in inorganic nanocrystals23, as discussed later.

sections.heading: Metallic nanoparticles
sections.text:
The use of MNPs can be traced back to Roman times, when they were used in glass manufacturing. The most famous example is the Lycurgus cup, which looks green in reflection and red in transmission because of the absorption and scattering of light by gold and silver nanoparticles that are dispersed into the glass in a colloidal form. Although this phenomenon has been known for a long time, only in recent years has it become possible to accurately understand the physical and chemical principles behind the optical properties of MNPs. Their characteristics mostly depend on localized surface-plasmon resonances, which are electromagnetic modes associated with the collective oscillations of free electrons confined on the surface of the nanoparticles. Surface plasmons are resonant with a particular frequency of the incident light and are highly sensitive to the geometry and dimension of the MNPs. For example, by increasing the aspect ratio of the MNPs, a redshift of the resonant wavelength of the surface plasmon is observed24. Furthermore, anisotropic MNPs such as rod-shaped nanoparticles exhibit two plasmon oscillation resonances, one along the transverse axis and the other along the longitudinal axis (FIG. 3a). Over the years, reliable and high-yielding preparation methods have been developed, and MNPs with different shapes and with sizes spanning from 1 to 100 nm can be readily synthesized. These methods can be classified into bottom-up — or atom-by-atom — and top-down methods, which involve the ablation or breaking of bulk materials. Because optical data storage techniques rely on light–matter interactions in the visible region — the region in which the surface-plasmon resonant peaks of gold, silver, aluminium and copper nanoparticles lie — these MNPs are suitable for practical uses. In particular, gold and silver nanoparticles are the most attractive candidates owing to their high chemical stability.
Various methods have been demonstrated that use MNPs in optical data storage applications. For example, the enhancement of the scattering cross-section at the surface-plasmon resonant frequency offers a pathway for high-contrast imaging25,26 that is suitable for the data-reading process. Furthermore, silver nanoparticles with different shapes and orientations have been used as physical storage elements of spectrally coded information27. They were fabricated by electron-beam lithography on an indium tin oxide-coated glass substrate with a sample spot of about 500 nm, which corresponds to the typical resolution limit of an optical microscope. The data readout was performed by using conventional optical far-field methods to detect the scattered light at different wavelengths depending on the surface-plasmon resonances of the MNPs. The spectral width of the resonance lines of the nanoparticles limited the enhancement of the data density, which nevertheless was reported to be five times that of conventional optical storage methods.

However, fabrication costs are prohibitive and the mass production of optical discs with this technique is unfeasible. A cheaper solution is to synthesize the MNPs via wet-chemical methods28,29 and incorporate them into a polymer host matrix, which can be then spin-coated on an arbitrary substrate.
Surface-plasmon resonances increase the efficiency of light absorption through multiphoton processes and excite electron–hole pairs in the material30. Electron–hole recombination results in fluorescent emission (FIG. 3b), providing another pathway for the imaging of the recorded bits. However, most of the electron–hole pairs relax to the Fermi level non-radiatively via electron–phonon energy exchange31. Consequently, the material heats up through a phonon–phonon process32. This pheno menon has been exploited to test metallic nanorods under irradiation at their surface-plasmon resonance frequency. When the temperature becomes higher than the melting point of the nanorods, they undergo a shape transition
into the thermodynamically stable, spherical phase. This photo-excitation-induced reshaping process has been used to (irreversibly) record bits of information.
The dependence of the surface-plasmon resonance on the wavelength and polarization of the laser beam has been exploited to achieve 5D optical data storage by multiplexing information in these two physical quantities in combination with the three spatial domains33. The recording medium consisted of layers of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) doped with gold nanorods spin-coated on a glass substrate. Addressing the right polarization and wavelength, multiplexed bits of information have been recovered individually and without crosstalk by two-photon excitation, obtaining a storage capacity of 1.6 TB for a disc the size of a DVD (FIG. 3c). The writing speed was 100 Mbit s−1 with an exposure time of 10 ns, but a value of 1 Gbit s−1 can be reached by using a high-repetition-rate laser. The writing and reading power were 60 mW and 0.1 mW, respectively. Further advances are expected by also encoding

The bit size in the discussed methods is still diffraction-limited; therefore, there is a compelling need for super-resolution optical data storage based on MNPs. Concerning the data reading, far-field super-resolution (<70 nm) optical microscopy has been demonstrated by extracting the nonlinear scattering response that is induced by the saturation effect in MNPs35. Because the scattering signal in gold nanoparticles exhibits a faster saturation at the centre of the focal spot, the saturated part of the scattering signal can be extracted by using a temporally modulated irradiation. Therefore, a reduction in the point spread function — the response of the imaging system to a point source — is obtained, and smaller particles can be resolved (FIG. 3d). The process requires a reading power of less than 1 mW.
Another method that has been utilized is enhanced dark-field illumination based on wavelength modulation36. Indistinguishable adjacent enhanced dark-field images of gold nanospheres, gold nanorods and silver nanospheres were modulated at their surface-plasmon resonance wavelengths. The MNPs were localized by fitting their point spread functions with a 2D Gaussian beam at different modulation wavelengths.
Additional possibilities for far-field super-resolution optical imaging of MNPs rely on one- or two-photon luminescence that is enhanced by the surface-plasmon resonance. Although the quantum yield of these processes is low, luminescence can potentially be tuned by controlling the on/off states of the luminescence of MNPs with light. So far, super-resolution techniques have allowed the reading of features at the nanoscale, but the size of the bits obtainable with the current writing methods is still limited by the diffractive nature of light. Consequently, a capacity of only a few terabytes can be achieved in a single optical data storage device, even if multi-dimensional multiplexing methods are used. In this regard, further studies are needed.
MNPs have been tested using mostly polymers as the host matrix. Therefore, their practical applications have been limited by degradation of the matrix under certain environmental conditions, such as high temperature and strong vibrations. In the case of gold nanoparticles, the lifetime of storage devices is related to the mechanical robustness of the nanoparticles, which can be tuned by controlling their phononic modes with specific adhesion layers37. The high melting point38,39 and photostability of MNPs offer the possibility of greatly enhancing the lifetime of optical data storage devices. Moreover, the energy required for information storage and far-field super-resolution microscopy based on MNPs is relatively low, owing to the field enhancement by the surface-plasmon resonances. This property makes MNPs promising for optical data storage with low power consumption.

sections.heading: Graphene and graphene oxide
sections.text:
After individual graphene sheets were first isolated40 in 2004, this newly available material has generated enormous interest among the scientific community because
of its exceptional mechanical, electrical, thermal and optical properties41. Graphene is a one-atom-thick (3.35 Å) planar carbon crystal with a hexagonal lattice42,43 (FIG. 4a). As early as 1947, it was realized44 that the dispersion relation for low energies is linear near the six corners of the hexagonal Brillouin zone, leading to a conical band structure that converges to a point. Therefore, electrons and holes near these six points behave as described by the Dirac equation for relativistic particles with spin 1/2, resulting in a remarkably high electron mobility at room temperature, with reported values43 in excess of 15,000 cm2 V−1 s−1. Furthermore, the linear dispersion enables stronger light absorption compared with other materials. Experimental results45 show that a single layer of graphene absorbs 2.3% of the radiation in the mid-infrared–ultraviolet range. Consequently, the electrons from the valence band are excited into the conduction band. For high irradiation intensities, the photogenerated carrier concentration increases, filling the states near the edge of the conduction and valence bands and preventing further absorption in a process called Pauli blocking46. Graphene can be readily saturated when exposed to light in the range from visible to near-infrared, owing to its broadband absorption and zero bandgap. The optical nonlinearity of graphene is resonantly enhanced by its strong linear absorption, and is broadband and wavelength-independent. For example, phenomena such as second-harmonic generation have been reported47 for graphene exposed to laser irradiation at 800 nm with a pulse length of 150 fs. Four-wave mixing to generate near-infrared, tunable light has been demonstrated using single- and multilayer graphene. The third-order susceptibility of graphene has been measured to be 10−7 esu, which is up to eight orders of magnitude larger than that of silica glass48.
Graphene can be produced by micromechanical exfoliation of highly ordered pyrolytic graphite, epitaxial growth, chemical vapour deposition and through the reduction of graphene oxide49. Whereas graphene prepared with the first three methods shows a (relatively) perfect structure and excellent properties, the reduction of graphene oxide offers a cost-effective solution because it can be obtained from inexpensive graphite via chemical processes. Graphene oxide is usually synthesized using the Hummers’ method50 or a modification thereof: that is, through the oxidation of graphite using concentrated acids in the presence of strong oxidants and subsequent exfoliation under sonication in aqueous solution. Although early studies described graphene oxide as a regular lattice composed of a repetition of discrete units, a precise chemical structure has not yet been outlined owing to the complexity of the material, its partially amorphous nature and practical difficulties in its characterization51. The widely accepted Lerf–Klinowski model52 describes graphene oxide as a non-stoichiometric structure with many oxygenated functional groups on its basal plane and at its edges (FIG. 4a). The broad range of reactive moieties enables the functionalization of graphene oxide through chemical modification and makes it insulating. The photoreduction of graphene oxide through the photothermal58 and photocatalytic59 effect has been recently demonstrated, paving the way for direct laser fabrication of graphene-based micro- and nanodevices and patterning60. The reduction of solid-state and in-solution graphene oxide by using a tightly focused ultra-fast laser is highly efficient, low cost and gives precise control over the process parameters61. The photoreduction of graphene oxide by femtosecond laser irradiation62,63 is illustrated in FIG. 4b. After irradiation, the intrinsic fluorescence of graphene oxide decreases, owing to the reduction of the oxygen-containing groups that are responsible for the signal. This change in fluorescence can be used to generate high-contrast images for data reading. The capacity of an optical storage device realized using this technique is 290 GB per disc62. Furthermore, the size of the data bits induced by photoreduction can be decreased by confining the photothermal effect through single-pulse laser irradiation62. Along with the decrease in the fluorescence signal, the refractive index can be largely tuned by laser irradiation (up to 10−1) for holographic recording. The unique fluorescence properties of graphene oxide and its giant refractive index changes can be exploited for multimode recording by combining bit-by-bit 3D optical data storage with holographic data storage on the same material platform (FIG. 4c).
The detection of nanoscale features on graphene and graphene-like materials has been demonstrated using transient absorption microscopy13,64 and fluorescence-quenching microscopy combined with STED65. These two techniques have potential for super-resolution reading in optical data storage applications. Transient absorption microscopy works by modulating the free-carrier density in graphene with a pump beam and by detecting the transient absorption response with a probe beam (FIG. 4d). The pump beam excites the electrons in the conduction band, decreasing the transient absorption of the probe beam owing to Pauli blocking. Consequently, the modulation is transferred from the pump beam to the probe beam. Super-resolution has been achieved by adding a non-modulated depletion beam in the pump-probe process13. The depletion beam has the shape of a donut to reduce the size of the effective point spread function at the focal spot. Furthermore, it has the same wavelength as the pump beam, but with higher intensity to saturate the transient absorption and deplete the pump-to-probe modulation transfer process. The required power is lower than 15 mW.
The other super-resolution method that is used on graphene is fluorescence quenching microscopy in combination with STED microscopy. Fluorescence quenching microscopy is based on non-radiative fluorescence (or Förster) resonance energy transfer (FRET)66 between a photoexcited electron donor and an electron acceptor. This process happens when a probing fluorophore is put in close proximity to a graphene or a graphene-like material. Owing to dipole–dipole interactions, the electrons from the excited states of the fluorophore relax to the ground state non-radiatively, whereas the electrons
of the acceptor are excited to the conduction band. The fluorescence of the donor is thus quenched, and the acceptor becomes excited; it then loses energy via heat or fluorescence emission in a process called sensitized emission. Graphene-based sheets exhibit energy transfers across the entire visible spectrum owing to their broadband absorption. Therefore, fluorescence quenching microscopy is not limited by the emission spectrum of the fluorophore in use, and can produce superresolution images of a wide combination of fluorophores and substrates, including metal, glass and plastic. Samples for fluorescence quenching microscopy can be conveniently prepared by spin-coating to create uniform thin films on an arbitrary substrate. The efficiency of FRET is highly dependent on the distance between donor and acceptor (typically 10–100 Å), the spectral overlap between the emission spectrum of the donor and the absorption spectrum of the acceptor, and the relative orientation of the emission dipole moment of the donor and the absorption dipole moment of the acceptor. Graphene sheets supported on a praseodymium-implanted yttrium aluminium garnet (Pr:YAG) crystal have been imaged using fluorescence quenching microscopy in combination with STED microscopy12. A resolution of 30 nm was achieved, requiring a power of 55 mW.
The experimental results reported above show that graphene and graphene oxide can be utilized for highquality super-resolution reading in high-capacity optical data storage applications. However, the size of the bits that can be fabricated using the currently available writing methods is still limited by the diffractive nature of light. Therefore, the capacity of optical data storage devices using 3D multiplexing techniques based on graphene or graphene oxide is expected to be less than 1 TB per disc. The photoreduction of graphene oxide to reduced graphene oxide through laser irradiation to induce permanent changes in the chemical and optical properties of graphene oxide can be also used for data recording. Graphene and graphene oxide exhibit high thermal stability67 and no photobleaching, which together guarantee a long lifetime for optical data storage devices based on these materials. The low power consumption required by the photoreduction of graphene oxide and by transient microscopy techniques makes graphene and graphene oxide good candidates for green data storage.

sections.heading: Semiconductor quantum dots
sections.text:
Semiconductor quantum dots are nanocrystals with sizes ranging from 2 to 10 nm composed of elements of the II-VI, III-V or IV-VI groups, such as CdS, ZnSe and InP. The electronic band structure of quantum dots changes from continuous to discrete as the size of the particles decreases and so their bandgap is precisely tunable. In addition, their emission peak depends on the particle size and constituent materials, and can be modulated to cover the regions from visible to near-infrared68 (FIG. 5a).

Typical values of single-photon absorption coefficients are (0.1–1) × 106 M−1 cm−1, and two-photon absorption co - efficients are (0.2–4.7) × 10−46 cm4 s photon−1. The quantum yield in the visible is 0.1–0.8 and in the near-infrared is 0.2–0.7, which is one to two orders of magnitude higher than that of organic dyes. Quantum dots display excellent photo stability and non-bleaching properties even after exposure to light for a prolonged time. Quantum dots have been used for optical data storage applications in two ways. The first method is to induce chemical or physical changes in the nano particles through laser irradiation. The second option is to use the quantum dots as electron donors to enhance the sensitivity of photoswitchable molecules. 3D optical data storage has been demonstrated by two-photon-induced permanent enhancement of the fluorescence signal of densely

The increase in the fluorescence signal is attributed to the photothermal annealing of the defect state related to the stack faults at the core–shell interface. Optical data storage realized by suppressing the fluorescence signal of rod-shaped CdSe–CdS quantum dots with laser-induced oxidation has also been demonstrated70,71.
Investigations have been carried out on quantum dots incorporated into photorefractive and photoisomerization materials by testing energy transfer processes within these systems. The mechanism by which the change in refractive index is realized in photorefractive materials is the electro-optic effect — the generation of an internal electric field as a result of light-induced spatial charge transport within the material. Modulation of the refractive index can be obtained by non-uniform illumination. This approach can be used for rewritable optical data storage: two-photon 3D optical data storage has been demonstrated by inducing photorefractive changes in LiNbO3 crystals using femtosecond laser irradiation72. Optical devices based on photorefractive polymers can be fabricated through simple and cost-effective preparation methods73,74. Two-photon-induced 3D recordings have been efficiently realized by doping CdS quantum dots into a photorefractive polymer75. Because quantum dots exhibit large one- and two-photon absorption cross-sections, their sensitivity is substantially enhanced under laser irradiation. In this demonstration75, the quantum dots served as electron donors through FRET and induced a variation in the refractive index of the polymer; the use of quantum dots as dopants also had the advantage of reducing the power needed for data writing from 20 to 12 mW with an exposure time of 30 ms. A capacity of 10 GB per disc was obtained with this method. In photoisomerization materials, the optical absorption spectrum can be altered by irradiation at an appropriate wavelength. The spectral change is due to the photoswitching between two different chemical structures. Also, photoisomers can be readily synthesized and can be rewritten76,77. The high polarization sensitivity of rod-shaped quantum dots has been exploited to achieve polarization-sensitive 4D optical data storage78,79. In this experiment79, the quantum dots were incorporated into photopolymers to induce polarization-sensitive FRET and initiate the isomerization process of the azo dye (FIG. 5b).
The lack of an optical method for reversibly modulating fluorescence limits the use of semiconductor quantum dots for application in super-resolution microscopy based on STED-like techniques. In fact, the broad excitation spectrum of quantum dots reaches even the red tail of their emission peak, causing re-emission upon irradiation with a STED beam. As a consequence, the depletion effect is cancelled. Only in recent years has a STED-like method based on ZnSe quantum dots doped with manganese enabled the detection of features down to 45 nm in size80. The emission of these quantum dots was mainly due to the Mn2+ ions. Excited-state absorption could re-excite the electrons from the excited states of the Mn2+ ions to the higher energy level of the
quantum dots, depleting the fluorescence of the ions with greater than 90% efficiency. A value of 92% for the depletion of fluorescence in very large CdSe–CdS quantum dots with a thick CdS shell has been achieved, and a resolution of 40 nm has been reported81. The result was almost complete suppression of non-radiative recombination and substantial enhancement of the stimulated emission efficiency for optical depletion. To date, STED super-resolution microscopy has been demonstrated with several commercially available quantum dots14. A depletion efficiency of 60% has been obtained by optimizing the overlap between the emission spectra of the quantum dots and the STED wavelength, and features with a size of 50 nm have been detected using a STED power of 344 mW (FIG. 5c).
Although high power consumption has been reported for data writing and STED super-resolution microscopy based on semiconductor quantum dots, they may find application in optical data storage in combination with other nanomaterials, in systems in which the function of the quantum dots would be to enhance the light sensitivity. This way, it would be possible to produce changes in the optical properties of the recording media, achieving super-resolution data writing for high-capacity optical discs.

sections.heading: Rare-earth-doped nanocrystals
sections.text:
RNCs have become a topic of widespread interest in biology, optoelectronics and photonics because they are potentially very useful for many emerging applications and have intriguing luminescent properties, in particular, up-conversion fluorescence. Photon up-conversion, also known as anti-Stokes-type emission, is a nonlinear optical phenomenon in which the sequential absorption of two or more low-energy photons leads to the emission of light with a shorter wavelength than that of the excitation light. Thus, RNCs can be used to convert near-infrared radiation into visible emission. In RNCs, up-conversion occurs through the combination of the energies of multiple photons that are sequentially absorbed in successive intermediate energy levels of the rare-earth ions. In contrast to other multiphoton absorption processes, such as two-photon absorption and second-harmonic generation, up-conversion has high quantum efficiency and can be effectively excited with relatively low pump intensities82. Up-conversion requires a long lifetime of the excited states and a ladder-like arrangement of energy levels with similar gaps. These characteristics have been observed mainly in rare-earth elements, which include the lanthanide series, yttrium and scandium.
RNCs consist of an inorganic crystalline host matrix with rare-earth ions added in low concentrations. The dopants provide luminescent centres, and the host crystalline lattice keeps them organized into optimal positions. The mutual distance between dopant ions, their spatial arrangement and their coordination number are important factors for efficient luminescence. The most common inorganic nanocrystal hosts for rare-earth ions are YAG, NaYF4, Y2O3, Gd2O2S and NaPrF4. Common preparation methods for RNCs are co-precipitation, thermal decomposition, hydro- or solvothermal synthesis,

Furthermore, the combination of RNCs with other types of materials such as ceramics, metals and poly mers through chemical approaches offers new possibilities for optical emission tuning and for the fabrication of composites with dual functionalities84.
The emission of RNCs covers a range from the blue to the red region of the spectrum, owing to the abundance of emission lines of rare-earth ions. The emission colour can be precisely controlled by optimizing the size and concentration of the rare-earth ions85, and the absorption of light can be improved by increasing the concentration of lanthanide dopants. However, radiationless deactivation may occur at high concentrations, and the process of cross-relaxation presents a serious limitation. The upper concentration limit for Er3+ is around 3%. At this value, the absorption of light is insufficient; consequently, strongly absorbing ions are additionally doped in the material to ensure efficient energy transfer. For up-conversion based on Er3+, the most widely used sensitizer is Yb3+, which can be co-doped into the lattice in high concentrations (18–20%). The energy separation between the energy levels in Yb3+ is very similar to that between the energy levels in Er3+, allowing efficient (quasi-)resonant energy transfer between the two ions. One example of RNCs for high-efficiency up-conversion fluorescence is the co-doping of the light sensitizer Yb3+ with the light emitters Er3+ or Tm3+ into the inorganic crystal NaYF4 (FIG. 6a). The Yb3+ ions absorb the photons at near-infrared frequencies and excite the adjacent Er3+ or Tm3+ ions via non-radiative energy transfer86. RNCs have a longer fluorescence lifetime (about 1 ms) than other fluorophores (about 1 ns) — this property is attributed to the Laporte forbidden 4f−4f transition of the rare-earth ions87.
Rare-earth-doped materials have been used in optical data storage by multiplexing data in the spectral domain through the spectral hole-burning method88. The zero-phonon absorption and the emission lines corresponding to the various electronic transitions are inhomogeneously broadened because of variations in the local environment of the host material. The spectral hole-burning method selectively bleaches the inhomogeneously broadened absorption lines by using a narrow-band irradiation source: this results in increased transmission (a ‘spectral hole’) at the selected frequency89 (FIG. 6b). The absorption corresponding to rare-earth ions is thus reduced when the electrons in the ground state are depopulated by photoexcitation. At cryogenic temperatures, the rare-earth ions inside the crystal have homogeneously broadened absorption lines that are narrow (1 to 10 MHz) compared with the inhomogeneously broadened absorption lines (0.5 GHz to 200 GHz). As a result, spectral multiplexing of 4,000 data bits at one spatial location has been achieved via the spectral hole-burning method by using a narrow-band laser. A capacity of 20 GB per disc was obtained90. The power of the writing and reading beams was 1.0 mW and 1.4 mW respectively, and the reading and writing speed was 20 MB s−1. Using this technique, the persistence time, which is commonly
defined as the data storage time, ranged from 10 ms to a few days.
Data multiplexing based on lifetime has been achie ved23 by controlling the fluorescence lifetime of NaYF4:Yb,Tm RNCs. The fluorescence lifetime was tuned from 48 to 668 μs by changing the distance between the sensitizer Yb3+ ions and the emitter Tm3+ ions by varying their concentrations in the NaYF4 nanocrystals23,91. Multiplexed data with different lifetimes has then been read out and decoded using fluorescence-lifetime optical microscopy (FIG. 6c).
Composite materials that combine RNCs and photochromic molecular switches, such as diarylethenes (DTEs), have been used to produce high-density storage devices based on the principle of luminescence modulation. 2D rewritable optical data storage using RNCs has been demonstrated by using a composite film consisting of alternating layers of organic and inorganic materials grown by sequential deposition on a silicon substrate92. The organic layer contained a robust photoluminescent DTE, which exhibited a reversible transformation between a ring-opened and a ring-closed state upon excitation with visible and ultraviolet light, respectively. The inorganic layer consisted of neatly assembled NaYF4:Yb:Er RNCs, which were made into a film using spin-coating deposition, the Langmuir–Blodgett method or evaporation-induced self-assembly. The storage device allowed data to be erased using ultraviolet radiation, rewritten using visible radiation to induce an energy transfer from the RNCs to the organic layers, and read using near-infrared radiation (FIG. 6d).

Up-conversion of Pr3+ can take place through an excitation from the ground state 3H4 into the intermediate state 1D2 by a laser pulse at 609 nm, followed by a second excitation into the emitting 4f5d state by a laser pulse at 532 nm. Thus, super-resolution imaging has been achieved by using a pump laser at 609 nm, a depletion laser at 532 nm and a probe laser at 532 nm. The 609-nm laser primarily populated the 1D2 state, which has a relatively long lifetime (150–200 μs). The donut-shaped 532-nm laser depleted the 1D2 state except for the RNCs at the centre of the donut. The surviving 1D2 state at the centre of the focus spot was excited by a Gaussian probe beam at 532 nm. The up-converted ultraviolet fluorescence of RNPs excited with visible light allowed background-free microscopy.
The unique electronic structure of RNCs and the high density of their energy levels make these nanomaterials suitable for implementation in STED methods for super-resolution reading in optical data storage applications. In particular, the precise tunability of the optical properties of RNCs allows the use of different types of lasers. Moreover, the intermediate energy levels of RNCs are metastable, which enables data readout with low excitation power, reducing the energy consumption for the overall process. RNCs in combination with other highly stable recording media may represent the solution to fabricating optical data storage devices with long lifetimes. Other advantages are that RNCs can be synthesized using several preparation methods and are suitable for spin-coating deposition for the large-scale production of optical devices.
Other nanomaterials for data storage Nanomaterials have also found application in data storage systems that are not based on optical techniques. For example, magnetic nanoparticles have been tested for the fabrication of magnetic data storage devices93,94. These devices have the potential to overcome the fundamental
physical limitation of about 1 Tbit in−2 (155 Gbit cm−2) of areal density in magnetic disks, which is set by the thermal stability of the recorded bits in magnetic materials95. Elements such as iron, nickel and colbalt, and their chemical compounds, are commonly utilized in magnetic nanoparticles for data storage purposes. A recording density of 3.3 bit in−2 (0.51 bit cm−2) has been demonstrated by using magnetic Co–Pd nanoparticles96. Furthermore, Pt–Fe nanoparticles enable magnetic data storage in bits with sizes down to 4 nm; hence, a high capacity can be achieved in a single data storage device97. Recently, a single-atom magnetic memory based on Ho atoms on MgO has been demonstrated98, in which the information was retained for a few hours. However, patterning large arrays of magnetic nanoparticles requires expensive nanolithography processes. It is not clear yet whether the benefits of using magnetic nanomaterials for data storage can surpass the drawback represented by the high fabrication costs.
Information storage into DNA molecules99 has attracted the interest of researchers and of large corporations such as Microsoft. DNA consists of two complementary and antiparallel polynucleotide chains, which are paired up and wrapped around the same axis to form a double helix with constant diameter (about 2 nm) and dextrorotatory winding. In recent years, DNA has been recognized as not only a biopolymer, but also a functional nanomaterial for bottom-up constructions in nanotechnology. DNA is very dense, with a theoretical maximum recording capacity of 455 exabytes per gram of single-stranded DNA100. In addition, it is extremely durable (half-life of over 500 years) and suitable for volumetric data storage. Many methods101 have been demonstrated for storing and retrieving information on DNA, and 739 kB of information have been reliably stored in a DNA code102. However, the lack of random data access and the cost of information writing and reading, which is estimated to be around US$12,620 per megabyte of storage102, make the use of DNA impractical for immediate application as an information storage medium.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text:
In this Review, we have surveyed the recent advancements in nanomaterials technology towards the next generation of optical data storage systems. The properties of four key types of inorganic nanomaterial — MNPs, graphene and graphene oxide, semiconductor quantum dots and RNCs — have been highlighted. The values of the benchmark parameters for these materials are reported in TABLE 1 and the experimental results regarding their implementation in far-field superresolution optical techniques are summarized in TABLE 2. Because it uses bit-by-bit writing and reading, far-field super-resolution optical data storage will enable format compatibility with currently available systems.
A particularly interesting perspective for the future of optical data storage relies on the development of nanocomposites based on RNCs in combination with graphene or graphene oxide. Rare-earth ions have a fluorescence lifetime that is two to three orders of magnitude longer than that of other fluorophores. In addition, RNCs offer the potential for low-power super-resolution data reading. Although the application of SPIN to RNCs has not yet been demonstrated, the recording of data may be achieved through the photocatalytic reduction of graphene oxide to reduced graphene oxide assisted by RNCs via FRET. Super-resolution writing and reading based on the combination of these two inorganic nanomaterials would provide a fully optical solution for data storage applications. Moreover, semiconductor quantum dots have recently been utilized for the photo catalytic reduction of graphene oxide through electron transfer under laser irradiation103. In this context, SPIN may be achieved by depleting the excited quantum dots to inhibit the reduction process. Further know ledge about the mechanism for these electron transitions is essential to achieve the ultimate goal of ultra-high capacity (petabytes in a single information storage device), ultra-long lifetime (at least a century) and ultra-low energy consumption (femtojoules per bit of storage) for the next generation of data centres, which might be enabled by the use of optical data storage devices based on inorganic nanomaterials.

metadata.abstractText: | The growing amount of data that is generated every year creates an urgent need for new and improved data storage methods. Nanomaterials, which have unique mechanical, electronic and optical properties owing to the strong confinement of electrons, photons and phonons at the nanoscale, are enabling the development of disruptive methods for optical data storage with ultra-high capacity, ultra-long lifetime and ultra-low energy consumption. In this Review, we survey recent advancements in nanomaterials technology towards the next generation of optical data storage systems, focusing on metallic nanoparticles, graphene and graphene oxide, semiconductor quantum dots and rare-earth-doped nanocrystals. We conclude by discussing the use of nanomaterials in data storage systems that do not rely on optical mechanisms and by surveying the future prospects for the field.
